description: Applies Sortes-style analysis to key concepts — where exactly is the boundary? Reveals hidden arbitrariness in categories and thresholds that arguments depend upon. Based on Dennett's use of the Sortes paradox to expose fuzzy concept boundaries.
researcher_question: Where are the boundary lines, and are they defensible?

boundary_analyses.how_used: string - how the text uses this concept

boundary_definition.explicit_definition: string - if the text defines it, what is the definition?
boundary_definition.implicit_definition: string - if implicit, what definition is being assumed?

sortes_probe.clear_case_inside: string - an obvious member of the category

borderline_cases.why_problematic: string - why it challenges the boundary
borderline_cases.argument_impact: string - how classifying it either way affects the argument

sortes_probe.continuum_exists: boolean - is there a continuum with no natural break?
sortes_probe.boundary_location: string - where the text draws the line
sortes_probe.boundary_justification: string - how/if the text justifies this location

alternative_boundaries.location: string - where else could the line be drawn
alternative_boundaries.justification: string - what would justify this alternative
alternative_boundaries.argument_impact: string - how this would change the argument

argument_dependence.how_critical: essential | important | minor - how much the argument depends on this boundary
argument_dependence.what_fails: string - what happens to the argument if boundary is contested

threshold_analyses.value: string - the specific threshold value if any

precision_illusion.appears_precise: boolean - does it look like a natural boundary?

categories: string - the categories in this system
category_systems.exhaustiveness: boolean - do they cover all cases?

which_boundaries: string - which category boundaries it stresses

meta.argument_critical_boundaries: number - boundaries the argument depends on
most_vulnerable_boundaries: string - concept_ids with highest arbitrariness + highest dependence

extraction.core_question: Where are the boundary lines, and are they defensible?
extraction_steps: The argument depends on a category distinction
The boundary of that category is not self-evident
Probing the boundary would reveal hidden arbitrariness
